direction.raw_text: My magazine doesn't pay because for stories.  It's not what you call ethical.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, but making up the facts as you go along is ethical?  Actually, I meant you.  You probably got severance or expenses or both.  I'll take your check. No credit cards.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Maggie) You've seen the post-its.  I've already got more juicy material than I need. Why should I pay you dollar one?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because I think you're writing on spec and with a first person interview, you might actually sell that thing. Ike knows she's right.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Too much.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Seven-fifty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Five hundred.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Six-fifty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Done. Scowling, he writes out the check and hands it to her.  Maggie looks at it and smile sweetly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : EXT. MAGGIE'S HOUSE - DAY Ike jogs alongside of Maggie on her bike.  Maggie parks her bike and they go inside her door to the house. INT. MAGGIE'S FOYER AND STAIRS - DAY Maggie leads Ike upstairs to her workroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pardon the mess.  I haven't cleaned since the fifth grade. INT. MAGGIE'S WORKROOM - LATER Insert on a cappuccino machine.  We PULL BACK and see Maggie and Ike standing at her work table.  An automatic cappuccino maker stands on the table.  Its base is made from a used paint mixing machine.  It looks very shiny and futuristic.  Maggie's logo "MAG" is on the side.  The machine shakes as it steams the cappuccino.  Ike notices another homemade machine on the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cont'd) What's this over here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a birthday present for my cousin. Put your finger in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cindy the manicurist. He puts his finger in the wrong hole of the machine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, the other one. He puts his finger in the correct hole.  She turns it on.  The brushes rotate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (laughing) This is wonderful.  You reconfigure all these industrial parts and you do something amazing with it. He looks around and spots some gadgets and lamps on another table. He walks to them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cont'd) Amazing.  Found industrial stuff. Willow lamp... Rasta lamp... He picks up one of the many logos on the counter.  Each boasts a "MAG" logo.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cont'd) Is this your preferred logo?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think so.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I like it.  This whole thing is pretty incredible. (studying a lamp) I think you could probably sell this lamp idea in New York.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe someday.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You afraid to try?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (stares at him) No, I'm not afraid.  Just... Maybe someday.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I'm impressed.  Absolutely incredible. (sitting) I didn't expect pink and lacy, but this isn't exactly a woman's room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What an incredible chauvinistic observation. INT. MAGGIE'S LIVING ROOM - A BIT LATER THAT DAY Maggie's showing Ike engagement rings.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's Brian's.  He took me ut canoeing on the lake and gave me the ring in a velvet box. Ike snores.  Maggie hits him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cont'd) (defensive) It was classic. Maggie hands Ike another ring.  This one is in the shape of a Grateful Dead rose.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cont'd) Gill.  Of course.  He proposed at the tie-dye t-shirt stand at a Dead concert. It was very sweet until he hallucinated that the drum set was a blood-sucking space alien.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Always a mood killer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Still sweet. Maggie hands Ike a third ring.  It's in the shape of a butterfly and studded with multi-color gems.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cont'd) George.  He proposed at a butterfly farm in St. Thomas.  The ring was inside a cocoon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (grimacing) It's a little "Silence of the Lambs" for me.  I can't believe you waited for the wedding to run.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's an entomologist!  I thought it was very unique. Now Maggie shows Ike the ring on her hand.  It's a gold "#1" with a diamond set into the number.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cont'd) And here we are at Bob.  He proposed during the seventh inning stretch... Ike touches her hand to examine the ring more closely.  Her surprise at his touch shows on her face as she finishes her sentence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cont'd) ... At an Oriole's game. She takes her hand down.  Ike steps away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wait.  Don't tell me.  The scoreboard lit up with "Mary me, Maggie." Ike picks up his cup of cappuccino and moves behind the couch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It was one of the most wonderful moments of my life.  Cal Ripken even applauded.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (stopping) Highly suspect.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you mean?  It was incredibly romantic!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe it's just me, but -- if you got to dress it up, it doesn't ring true. Ike moves back to the couch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cont'd) I think the most anybody can honestly say is, "Look..." (sits on the arm of the couch) "I guarantee that we'll have tough times.  I guarantee that at some point one or both of us will want to get out of this thing.  But I also guarantee that if I don't ask you to be  mine, I'll regret it for the rest of my life. Because I know in my heart -- you're the only one for me" Maggie stares at Ike for a beat.  His words have taken a little bit of her breath away.  She covers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I like it. She moves from the fireplace to a chair and sits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cont'd) I'd like it better on a scoreboard. (lightly) Is that how you proposed when you asked your wife to marry you? Ike is taken aback.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cont'd) Don't look so surprised, you've got divorce written all over you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm a work in progress.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So?  Is that what you said to her?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.  I think I said something eloquent like, "So, uh -- maybe we should, ya know.  What do you think?"
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now that's romantic.  A proposal like that and you didn't find eternal bliss? What went wrong? Ike takes a swallow of cappuccino.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe you should ask her some time. Ever thought of that? Ike is restless.  He stands up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Call me crazy, but I believe that check I gave you entitles me to ask the questions for a while. Ike puts down his cup of coffee, gets his tape recorder and sits close to Maggie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fair enough. (thinks a beat) Actually... Maggie move to TV.  She picks up Ike's stolen post-it notes and her wedding video on top of the TV, and goes to the front door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cont'd) I'll just need one more day to make sure your check clears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ow!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : EXT. HALE STREET - THE NEXT DAY Ike and Maggie drive in Maggie's truck.  They pull up in front of a Bridal Shop. A spectacular dress fills the small window.  It's beautiful, romantic, sexy.  Maggie and Ike can be seen in the reflection.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Even with everything that's happened I've still never been married and I still deserve a beautiful dress.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Agreed. Maggie gives Ike a smile that lights up the sky.  They go inside. INT. BRIDAL SHOP - DAY The place is fairly large and prosperous, probably the place to go in the Tri-County area.  A little FLOWER GIRL, 10, is being fitted on the pedestal in the middle of the room.  A saleswoman, POLLY, has taken the flower girl under her wing.  They are both under the expert eyes of a stern looking woman, MRS. WHITTENMEYER, the shop owner.  Also, the girl's MOTHER is there watching. POLLY (to the mother) She'll be the prettiest little flower girl in your daughter's wedding.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Whittenmeyer.  Hi, Polly! The flower girl sees Maggie and runs and hides behind Polly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi, Maggie.  You'll have to excuse her, Maggie.  Some of the children are afraid of you since you dragged that little boy up the aisle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't drag. (then to the girl) He tripped on his shoelaces. Mrs. Whittenmeyer comes forward to greet Maggie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . WHITTENMEYER You've come for your dress.  Good! I'll get it from the back. Maggie leads her to the front window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (happily) Actually, I would like to get this dress. She points to the dress.  She smiles back to Mrs. Whittenmeyer, expecting her to share her joy.  Mrs. Whittenmeyer darkens.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . WHITTENMEYER (to Polly) Polly, take Leslie into change. (then, to Maggie) But the one you have on hold is lovely.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (pleasantly) Yes.  But I've changed my mind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . WHITTENMEYER It's one thousand dollars. Maggie is keenly aware of Ike listening in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have one thousand dollars.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . WHITTENMEYER (firmly) The other one is only three hundred dollars. Maggie lowers her voice, hoping to lessen the humiliation of the moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is this dress for sale?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . WHITTENMEYER It just seems like an awful lot of money to spend on one of your dresses, Maggie... You only wear them for about ten minutes. Ike watches with regret as Maggie's child-like enthusiasm drains away, her happy mood crushed by the tactless assault of the shop owner.  He's starting to see that it's no always easy being Maggie. There's a tremor in her voice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, that's a good point. (then, sitting) The other dress is nice. Ike calls out to Mrs. Whittenmeyer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs. Whittenmeyer.  May I talk to you for a second? She walks over to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cont'd) I don't know much about this kind of thing.  I'm from out of town.  You're a salesperson, right?  You're here to sell wedding dresses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . WHITTENMEYER (huffy) Yes.  I've been here for thirty years.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Perfect.  Because Miss Carpenter is here to buy one.  But not just any one. She wants that one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . WHITTENMEYER It's a thousand dollars! Ike goes over and takes the mannequin out of the window.  Mrs. Whittenmeyer catches the wig as he puts the mannequin under his arm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cont'd) Look, Aunt Bea, we're buying this beautiful dress and anything else she wants or I'm coming back here with a squirt gun filled with India ink. Mrs. Whittenmeyer wilts under Ike's fierce gaze.  She turns to Maggie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . WHITTENMEYER Will he really do that? Maggie gives her a look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . WHITTENMEYER (cont'd) (to Maggie) Well, why don't you pick out some accessories while I get this ready, dear.  Polly, will you come help me, please? Polly comes to help carry the mannequin away. ANGLE ON POLLY AND MRS. WHITTENMEYER:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (whispering to Mrs. Whittenmeyer) It's a thousand dollars.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . WHITTENMEYER Shhhh!  The man has ink! Maggie looks gratefully at Ike.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tough to spend money in this town. TIME CUT: A FEW MINUTES LATER: Ike sits as he hears Maggie's voice behind him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (o.s.) What do you think? Ike turns around.  Maggie is standing on the pedestal, wearing the dress and looking unbelievably gorgeous.  She is overwhelming to behold and Ike has to struggle to keep his face under control.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (stammering) You look... uh... You look fine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fine.  The newspaper's upside down. That's better than fine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bob will be very happy. She glows.  Then the moment between them is broken as she suddenly remembers something and grabs the veil off her head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bob!  I almost forgot!  I have to meet Bob! INT. DINER - DAY This is a great place -- a major hub of social life in Hale.  The food is greasy and good, Mrs. Pressman is the waitress, and the CROWD the essence of what is wonderful about a small town.  Bob, Maggie and Ike sit on the counter.  Mrs. Pressman CHUFFS about the luau, then moves around the corner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs. Pressman, I think we're ready to order.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . PRESSMAN We're out the special because somebody... (indicates COOK with head) ... didn't order enough sausage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let me have the garden omelette.  Egg whites only. Ike looks at Maggie.  He'd bet a thousand bucks on what she'd say next.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll have the same.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (clears his throat) Of course.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What was that?  I can't order  my eggs without sarcasm?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Neutral corners you two.  You're on the same team now.  Any more fighting and it's fifteen minutes in the penalty box. (gently, to Ike) Maggie's the nicest person you'll ever meet.  But she's always focusing out there.  She's got to start focusing more in here. (taps his chest) That's why she's had some -- whatever you want to call it -- problems in the past. (to Maggie) That's what we're working on -- focus. Right, Maggie?  Focus on Maggie.  Focus on Bob. As Bob has been talking, Ike has been watching Maggie's face. The joy seems to have drained out of her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (quietly) Right.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Ike) I lead Maggie through a visualization exercise.  All the sports shrinks use this head stuff.  Visualize the end zone, if you catch my drift. Bob takes out a notepad and hands it to Maggie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cont'd) Here's today's mantra: "It's an open field to Big Bob."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell me.  When you get to the altar, will you spike the bouquet?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know, there's no... Before Maggie can finish, Ike intercepts her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I'm off.  A reporter's work is never done. (heading to the door) Mrs. Pressman, thank you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . PRESSMAN Tootaloo. INT. ATLANTIC HOTEL - MOMENTS LATER GRANDMA JULIA (V.O.) I'd like to explain about the weddings. There are reasons why they didn't come off.  Three weddings, no "I do's".  You can't believe how much cake we were left with.  I should weigh three hundred pounds.  I don't think her father minded spending so much money on booze that nobody drank. We hear Grandma as through the hotel doors, we see Maggie exit the diner.  She gets a bag from inside the cab of her truck and comes inside the hotel where she finds Ike talking to Grandma, who is having tea with her friend, NETTA.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ike... Hi, Grandma.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gram here was going to give me the skinny on why you run from marital bliss.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Right, cover your ears, Netta.  It's not that she's afraid of the wedding, she's afraid of the wedding night. Innocent girls are terrified of "the one-eyed snake". (getting into it) Why, when I was a virgin bride, I took a knitting needle with me into the bed... Ike winces.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Actually, Grandma, I charmed the one- eyed snake awhile ago.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, yeah, I forgot.  I'll tell you one thing, your grandpa didn't forget that wedding night. (no Netta) You can take your hands off your ears, Netta.  Your tea's getting cold.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can you excuse us a minute? (then to Ike) May I have a word with you, please? Maggie moves toward door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bye, Netta... Bye, Grandam. He steps over to Maggie in the doorway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I found this and didn't know if it was something interesting. Maggie hands Ike a 30-year-old LP: Miles Davis' "Kind of Blue."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (excited) Oh, my God -- It's Miles Davis.  This is "King of Blue"!  This is the original recording.  Hard to find in good condition.  Where did you find this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (casual) It was in the attic.  It was jus sitting there gathering dust.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's valuable.  Hang onto it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.  You take it. She steps outside, leaving Ike with the record.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hmmm... Figuring out what kind of music I like and then finding me a rare album. You're not trying to soften me up, are you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No -- I'm cleaning an attic.  I wouldn't attempt the impossible. She turns and walks back to the diner where Mrs. Pressman is outside watering plants.  Ike looks after Maggie and then back down at the record in his hand.  Somehow it makes him sad.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : INT. IKE'S CAR - LATER THAT DAY Ike drives through Hale gobbling french fries from the fast food bag in his lap.  Ike passes THE INN HALE BAR, same dump of a tavern he talked to bartender at. ANGLE ON: MAGGIE'S CAR parked a few cars down.  He pulls over and parks.  He gets out and speaks into his tape recorder. INT./EXT. THE INN HALE BAR -- DAY Ike approaches the window of the bar.  There's a DRUNK MAN and a DOG sitting outside.  Inside, we see two figures from the back, arms around each other.  One is definitely Maggie.  The other is definitely not Bob.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (coaxing) C'mon.  Let's go. As Maggie helps the man get up,  we see that it's Walter, Maggie's father -- dead drunk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (belligerently) I haven't had any fun since you got your driver's license... They stumble and lurch, exiting the bar toward Maggie's car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not exactly having fun, either... Steady.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Dog) Good boy, Port Hole.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His name is Skipper, Dad... Steady.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I changed it. (then to Drunk) See you later, Mr. Travis. (then to Maggie) That guy has a problem... Maggie, you can run everyone's life but your own. Maggie's having trouble keeping him steady as she opens the car door.  Ike is there in a flash to help her pull Walter into the car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cont'd) Good daughters let their fathers pass out. Walter passes out on the front seat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (without difficulty) Ike... Please don't write anything about this -- IKE No.  Forget about it.  Don't even think about it. Maggie looks at him with real gratitude.  She swings the car door shut.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Watch your leg, Dad. (then to Ike) I'm so tired of this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why don't you let him sleep it off in the trunk. I'll take you for a ride. Then we'll come back for him. (to Drunk on bench) Keep an eye on him. DRUNK MAN I'm too loaded.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was talking to the dog. (turning to Maggie) All right? Maggie thinks about this for a moment.  She takes a deep breath.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay... I'll just grab my jacket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : EXT. ROAD - LATE DUSK TO NIGHT Establishing of Ike's car driving. INT. IKE'S CAR - LATE DUSK TO NIGHT Maggie and Ike ride along.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My dad managed a business and two mistresses.  He wanted me to be a novelist.  More? Maggie nods,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cont'd) My mother wanted me to become a musician.  0 for two.  But at least I'm a journalist and we all know journalism is literature in a hurry. EXT. IKE'S CAR - COUNTRY ROAD - NIGHT Ike and Maggie stare forward.  Both seem in melancholy moods. They're beginning to sense they're in trouble here.  Suddenly, the car falters and jerks.  It shows to a stop on the shoulder of the road.  The car backfires and smokes. EXT. IKE'S CAR - COUNTRY ROAD -  NIGHT Ike and Maggie sit in the steaming car for a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your filter's clogged.  This takes unleaded.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can you fix it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: First I have to find some tools.  I need a half and a nine-six-tenth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (removing his glasses) Of what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (in amazement) Wrenches.  My dad's gonna love that one. Maggie slams the food closed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kind of isolated.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah.  It's kind of nice. An uncomfortable silent pause.  Ike breaks the moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's one thing we New Yorkers know how to do is hail a cab.  If there's no cab, we walk. Ike stares off down the road.  Maggie indicates a building in the distance, then turns off the car lights.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can get some tools over there.... and save the battery... There's one thing we country girls know how to do is cut across a field.  It's quicker. Maggie points diagonally across the field to where a gas station sign glows and the lights from the outer house twinkle. He smiles and follows her into the field.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cont'd) Be careful of snakes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Snakes?  Are you serious?  I don't like snakes.  I've never even seen a snake. He steps carefully into the field, then hops gingerly toward Maggie. MOMENTS LATER Maggie leads Ike through a cornfield.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you think there's only one right person for everybody? Ike chooses his words carefully.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.  But I think attraction is too often mistaken for rightness. Attraction is very misleading.  And if it's mutual, it's well, terribly distracting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes it is.  And it doesn't mean anything. Ike nods as they come to a wooden fence.  She puts her hand on his shoulder.  Ike puts his hands around her waits to give her a boost over the top.  We see the flicker of misunderstanding cross Maggie's face at the initial contact.  Neither of them moves -- forward or back, but the electricity is obvious. ANGLE ON:  Ike.  His conflicted feelings are apparent.  With difficulty, Maggie straightens up and they both quickly remove their hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cont'd) (lightly) I suddenly forgot how to climb a fence. They look at each other for a moment, then:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (breaking the moment jokingly) "Tools". She climbs over the fence on her own and Ike follows.  They see an old guy, LIONEL, whittling on a porch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cont'd) Lionel, can I borrow some tools?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, we need a half and nine- sixteenths.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gonna bust out of another wedding?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're sure well known around here. EXT. FISHER AND ELLIE'S BUILDING - THE NEXT DAY Establishing shot. INT. FISHER AND ELLIE'S KITCHEN (NYC) - DAY INT. IKE'S HOTEL ROOM - DAY INTERCUT BETWEEN TWO LOCATIONS: Ike sits on his bed, on the phone, working and eating his breakfast.  He's watching Maggie's wedding tape again.  Fisher is cooking an elaborate breakfast.  Ellie rushes around getting ready for work.  He is on the phone to Ike.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (into phone) Yes, well, my theory was that she may be running because she gets attention... Negative attention is attention. Like when women whack you on the street because of your column, that's negative attention.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) This is about her negative attention, not mine.  Did you get the reimbursement for the dress yet?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (into phone) No, I'm paying for the dress.  Do you think she's still gonna run?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) I don't know. Ellie enters the kitchen, hears the question and shakes her head to herself.  If only these boys would give it up. INT. IKE'S HOTEL ROOM - CONTINUOUS He is finding it very hard to gloat.  Fisher is annoying him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (into phone) Look -- I'll be in there later today. I'll come by and tell you all about it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) You're coming here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (into phone) Yeah.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) Then come for dinner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (into phone) Okay, we'll order out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) Order out like a Philistine, when you got the Galloping Gourmet here?... Ike hangs up and watches more of the George Swilling wedding video. INT. NEW YORK BAR - DAY The bar from the opening scene.  GEORGE SWILLING, the same man Ike talked to before, is sitting on a stool, nursing his drink. He looks better.  Ike enters.  George looks up and recognizes Ike, who takes the bar stool next to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get this man a Kamikaze.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Splendid dissection of Maggie Carpenter, very professional job. Ike sits and leans over to George.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (whispers) You could have told me you were fiance number three.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And end up in the papers?  I've been humiliated enough already to last a lifetime, thank you.  I'm sorry she got you canned.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's a cacophony of contradictions.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I'm writing another article on the cacophony.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ah, can't stay away from her, can you? Like a moth to a flame.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Guess you'd know about that.  You're an entomologist, right?  How's business?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (taking a sip of his drink) Not bad.  I was traveling around studying the reproductive and migratory patterns of locusts when Maggie met me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (sarcastic) Neuter a locust, feed the world. GORGE Not the world.  Just Africa and China. Ike wipes the smirk off his face.  Like Maggie's other men, this guy has a worthy accomplishment under his belt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cont'd) You know Maggie was the only girl I ever met who would hold my tarantula. On the first date.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cont'd) So, tell me, George, why do you think she ran?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Same as you said.  What did you call her?  A "man-eater", "a devouring death goddess."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't think that's why she ran.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why do YOU think she ran? Ike sips his drink before answering.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know.  I'm working on it.  I was on the wrong track.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And you defending her?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.  I call it like I see it.  I'm a journalist.  I'm a truth teller.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Unbelievable, she got to you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, please! GORGE Join the club. (passing him his drink) Here, you need this more than me. George heads out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (protecting, taking his tape recorder out of his pocket) I'm writing an article, I'm getting paid to do this, it's going to be a cover story, it's going to be published ... The facts will be read someday. As George pauses in the doorway, Ike holds up his tape recorder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cont'd) What kind of eggs did she like?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Poached, just like me. George exits.
direction.name: direction

location: NEW YORK STREET/FISHER AND ELLIE'S BUILDING
result.heading: EXT.

direction.raw_text: : EXT. NEW YORK STREET/FISHER AND ELLIE'S BUILDING - DAY Ike walks down a street toward Ellie and Fisher.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : INT. FISHER AND ELLIE'S APARTMENT (NYC) - NIGHT Ellie is on the phone as Fisher enters with beer.  Ike sits at the piano.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (sarcastically) Overpriced nice apartment and Chinese takeout.  That's New York living.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (into phone) ... Just call me when you have it. (hangs up, then to Fisher) Ike, how is the story coming?  Is she a man-eater?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Or a vegetarian?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Or does she pick "NGB'S" -- "Nice Guys, But..."  Nice guys, but I'm cheap. Nice guys, but he lives with his mom... Nice guys, but he just out of prison.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No... They're interesting guys.  Each one of these guys has something going for him.  I mean, one's been up Everest. Another's become a priest.  One's a pretty good guitar player.  And this guy today tried to end world hunger, if you can believe that...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whoa, Ike.  Getting a complex, buddy?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fisher, let him talk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (sits) But one of those guys -- not one of them -- knew her at all.  Each one was convinced that she was perfect for them, but they didn't see her.  And she never showed up so they couldn't see her. It's a very symbolic thing happening. She becomes what she thinks they wanted to be. Fisher doesn't like the sound of this.  He glances at Ellie, who is looking very interested.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (in shock) Ike is turning sensitive and I can't bear to watch.  I'm going to make a fresh pot of tea. The phone rings as Fisher exits.  Ike goes to the piano as Ellie picks up the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (into phone) Yeah... Oh, Jay... Okay... Bye. (hangs up, then yells to Fisher) Fisher, don't forget the fortune cookies. She joins Ike at the piano.  Ike gets serious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is that what I did to you?  Is that what happened?  Did I just not see you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.  No, you didn't. He hugs her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (heartfelt) Well -- I'm sorry, I'm really sorry, Ellie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry, too. (beat) Wow.  That only took us between years to say. Ellie blinks back sentimental tears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : EXT. TROUT'S BARN - THE NEXT NIGHT We hear Hawaiian music.  We see a truck with GUESTS drive up and HULA DANCERS through barn slats. INT. TROUT'S BARN - NIGHT It's a small barn that's been converted into a luau with a bar. A BAND plays for two hula dancers.  The Trouts had decorated it as a little slice of Hawaii.  There are tiki lights, numerous rented plastic palm trees and fiberglass copies of Hawaiian statuary.  Strings of colored lights crisscross the ceiling. It looks like a Hawaiian high school gym on prom night. Maggie's family, Mrs. Trout and people we've already met, and more, are here, milling around wit tropical drinks garnished with umbrellas.  Plastic leis abound and most people have managed to find their old Hawaiian shirts. As we come in, the hula dancers finish their applause and Mrs. Trout announces.  Hula dancers stop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Welcome to our annual country luau.  As you know, Betty and I got married on the rim of the crater, Diamond Head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . TROUT (grabbing the microphone) This year, we're dedicating our first dance to the soon-to-be newlyweds, the King and Queen of Hawaii, Maggie and Bob. The couple enters.  Bob is a goody bronzed god in his King Kamahamela outfit.  Maggie is spectacular in her authentic looking Hawaiian Princess get-up.  But her face reflects none of the festivities around her.  Every now and then, she looks up and glances around for Ike, hating herself for it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . TROUT (cont'd) King and Queen, dance. Maggie and Bob start to dance as the Quarter sings "Aloha Oe."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . TROUT (cont'd) Everybody dance. Everybody dances.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : Maggie and Bob pose for pictures with some of the guests.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . TROUT Pictures of the King and Queen. Dennis poses with Maggie.  Cory poses with Bob.  Mrs. Trout runs out of film and goes to get more, leaving Peggy and Maggie alone. Peggy whispers to Maggie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lighten up, wahine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lighten up, what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This party is for you and Bob.  Get your mind off the reporter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I haven't seen him in twenty-four hours. It just gives me the creeps a little bit. I'd feel better if I knew where he was.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (nods to door) Would it? ANGLE ON:  Ike just entering the party.  At least he tried. He's got a tropical sheet wrapped around his pants and shirt. He walks to the bar and is greeted warmly by Lee.  Maggie gets very flustered.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cont'd) What are you doing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (after a beat) I'm going to go dance with Bob. Because he's the man. (referring to her headdress) I like those grapes. Maggie dances affectionately with Bob as Mr. Trout, tending bar, greets Ike.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, Mr. Graham, welcome to our luau. What can I get you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You got something without a toy in it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : A LITTLE LATER - CLOSE ON A pair of expressive pantomime "A Little Grass Shack". PULL BACK TO REVEAL: Mrs. Trout is on stage, introducing hula contestants.  Grandma judges the Hawaiian dancing.  The party is at full tilt -- a little wild, a little goofy.  Some guests (Bob, Cindy, Cory, Lee and Ted) do the limbo.  Walter, Mrs. Pressman doesn't turn as she hears him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aloha.  That's a very fetching headdress you're wearing. Ike leans into Maggie, enjoying the smell of her hair.  She notices, but acts casual.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where did you disappear to?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Missed me bad, huh?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : All the guests start banding their pineapple cups.  Walter rises unsteadily, lifting his pineapple.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . TROUT Attention.  Listen to Walter.  Listen close, he slurs. (then) Shut up, wahines!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In the tradition that has grown through the years, it is now Toast Time!  First up, our host, "A Honey of a Beekeeper", Lou Trout.. Lou Trout stands with his glass raised.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: May the groom's heart be filled with hopes and the bride's feet be filled with lead! There are shouts of "Hear hear!"  Walter roars.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . TROUT May the pitter-patter of little feet not be Maggie's.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . PRESSMAN May the gifts be returned!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: May the back of the dress be as pretty as the front! The laughter swells and swells, led by Walter. ANGLE ON: Ike watches as Maggie takes the heat, raising her glass along with the others.  Bob raises his glass like the good sport he is. Ike can't believe it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know the old saying, "You're not losing a daughter..."  Well, I'd like to! Walter gets a bit laugh.  He goes again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cont'd) Maggie may not be Hale's longest running joke... (under her breath) Maggie finishes the punchline along with his father.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But she's certainly the fastest. Uproarious laughter.  Maggie looks terribly pained.  Ike's had enough.  He pushes himself to his feet.  Walter is thrilled.  He shushes the CROWD.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cont'd) Oh, look, Mr. Graham, how about a toast?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know, give me a minute. (to Maggie) Are you all right with this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Excuse me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you all right with this?  You think this is funny?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't and I don't think you should...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a joke.  They're kidding.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (yell) Come on and give us a toast.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You want me to make a toast?  Okay... I'll give you a toast.  To Maggie's family and friends.  May you find yourselves the bull's eye of an easy target.  May you be publicly flogged for all of your bad choices and may your noses to rubbed in all of your mistakes... Ike watches their reaction.  The silence is deafening.  All the guests stare at Maggie.  Mortified, she holds back tears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . TROUT That was funny. (a pause) But enough toasts, let's hula.  Let's start the music up. She gets everyone up to hula.  Band plays fast tune.  Maggie walks through the CROWD down the steps and outside.  Ike follows, but Peggy grabs a coat for her.  Bob watches her go as Cory approaches.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, Bob.  I got twenty dollars bet on--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not now. Bob rushes after Maggie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (calling after her) Maggie.  Maggie. (to Ike,  handing him a jacket) Here.  She may need this.  It's not really Hawaii. Ike exits.  Then, Bob comes over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where'd Maggie go?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, she just went to get me something from the car. Cory comes over with Dennis to Bob and Peggy.  BOB/PEGGY/CORY/ DENNIS CHUFFA:  About Bart Starr and football.  (Which keeps Bob from going outside to follow Maggie).  Bob thinks about it. EXT. TROUT'S BARN - NIGHT Ike runs after Maggie.  He grabs her arm and turns her to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm the only goddamn person in there pulling for you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You humiliated me!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, Maggie, I defended you. Humiliating you is what everyone else is doing.  It's the theme of this party.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I had it under control.  Now they feel sorry for me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, they should.  Because they're about to watch you hang yourself again. Maggie has no response.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cont'd) -- Tell me something, do you really care about Mount Everest?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's fun!  It's high.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Or the sexual habits of locusts?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That was very interesting research George was doing!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What kind of Dead Head gets a temporary tattoo?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I already explained about that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And where you ever really going to run the leper colony in Molokai?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (wincing) Brian told you that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Or maybe you just wanted to wear the headdress.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Every one of those times I was being supportive.  Something you won't understand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Supportive?  You weren't being supportive.  You were being scared. Just like now.  You are the most lost woman I have ever laid eyes on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lost!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's right.  You're so lost you don't even know how you like your eggs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What!?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With the priest, you liked them scrambled.  With the Dead Head, fried. With the bug guy, poached.  Now it's egg whites only, thank you very much.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's called changing your mind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, that's called not having a mind of your own.  What are you doing, Maggie? You really want to let that man drag you up Annapuma on your honeymoon?  You don't want to climb Annapuma.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes I do!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No you don't.  You want a man who will lead you down the beach with his head over your eyes just so you can discover the feel of the sand under your feet. You want a guy who will take you into a cave with a thousand candles just to read you a poem.  You want a man to wake you up at dawn because he's burning to talk to you and he can't wait another minute to find out what you'll say.  Am I right? He's laid her flat.  Maggie can't speak.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cont'd) Am I right? She fights back angry tears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stop.  Stop it!  I'm getting married on Sunday, and you're just trying to make me run!  Why?  Because you're a cynical, exploitative, mean-hearted creep who wouldn't know real love if it bit him in the armpit!  And all you do is tear other people down and-and-and laugh at them, and criticize what they do, because you're too afraid to do anything yourself!  I read your column. You never wrote one about you.  I'm not the only one who's lost and you know it! Am I right?  Well?  Am I right? ANGLE ON:  Bob comes outside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mag.  Help me out here.  Green Bay. Right guard. Both Maggie and Ike are breathing hard.  Bob comes up to Maggie and gives Ike a very hard look as he puts his arm around his fiancee.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cont'd) You know... Blocked Bart Starr, crewcut ... Are you okay? Maggie adjusts her face as best she can.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let me take you back inside, okay? She lets him lead her away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jerry Kramer. Ike looks at her drooped shoulder and he shakes his head and walks to his car. EXT. HALE METHODIST CHURCH - THE NEXT DAY Peggy and Cindy arrive for the rehearsal.  They leave Cindy's dog in Peggy's car and walk to the church.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell me, why does Maggie need another wedding rehearsal and two days before the wedding?  She's already done this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bob is making her visualize the ceremony.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : INT. HALE METHODIST CHURCH - NIGHT They are in the church proper now.  Peggy waits in a pew as Bob leads Maggie and Ike up the back steps of the church.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Maggie) Okay, we're ready.  Want me to have Ike leave now? Maggie turns on Ike with "cheerful" hostility.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.  No -- Actually, let's make Ike the pastor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd rather not.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (sarcastically) Come on, it'll give you a great view. It's perfect. (seeing Peggy) Hey. Maggie smiles at Bob.  Ike sighs and goes with it.  Bob pulls Ike to the head of the aisle and places him.  Peggy follows Maggie into the foyer to get ready.  Cindy sits with Ted at the organ.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Team effort, Pastor Ike... Cindy, ready? (after no response) Cindy, come on. Cindy leaves to join the girls in the foyer. INT. CHURCH FOYER - THAT MOMENT Once in the privacy of the foyer, Peggy and Maggie talk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's going to be the pastor?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yep.  I want him to be front and center and to watch everything.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What happened at the luau?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (flustered) ... I don't even want to talk about the luau. (then seeing a hanging rope) What's this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's for the bell. Cindy joins them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bob's in a hurry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't be nervous, Maggie.  Let us visualize.  Remember what Bob said? "Be the ball."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Sink the putt."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Make the shot."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Nothing but net."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Never say die." Maggie puts her hands up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go! Peggy and Cindy exit.  Maggie pulls the bell rope and sways back and forth as she rings the bell. INT. CHAPEL - THAT MOMENT It is Maggie's turn to enter.  They all turn expectantly.  Too much time passes.  Ted plays the organ, then stops.  Maggie swings back and forth in the foyer doorway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Honey, are you okay? Maggie stops ringing the bell and pulls herself together.  She walks into the aisle looking a little shaky.  She takes a few tremulous steps slowly with her eyes closed, peeking occasionally with one eye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (taking off his jacket) At this pace, it could be an evening wedding.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hold it!  Hold it!  I think we're taking this too fast. He begins to pace.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cont'd) We need to limber you up a little. You're tensing. (thinks a moment; to Ike, moving him to groom's spot) You stand here and be me so she knows how far she'll have to go. (then to Maggie) I'm going to walk with you. Bob goes to Maggie and walks behind her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cont'd) Visualize!  Visualize!  It's game time. ANGLE ON: Maggie walking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cont'd) You are the football.  You're spiraling through the air towards the hands of the groom. She proceeds down the aisle.  Bob behind her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (eyes down) Yes, I'm spiraling through the air. ANGLE ON: Maggie raises her eyes and sees Ike in front of her as groom. Ike and Maggie lock gazes.  If they had to, they couldn't look away.  All the things unspoken are now communicated -- the love, the longing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cont'd) I streak towards the goal line. Maggie's pace quickens.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cont'd) And I land on the goal line. ANGLE ON: Bob beams to see Maggie's eager arrival at Ike's side.  He switches off the music and proceeds like a proud coach to be the pastor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay, I'm the pastor.  Dearly beloved, blah, blah, blah.  So on and so forth. Ra ta ta ta.  Yabada dabada.  I now pronounce you man and wife.  Kiss the bride, badum dum. (then moving toward Ted) We have the crescendo that leads to us right back down the aisle and out the... Ike kisses Maggie.  It is a world class, Olympic kiss.  It is a kiss that changes everything and can never be taken back.  It is a kiss you only get once in your life. NEW ANGLE: Bob's smile dies.  Cindy's mouth drops open as the kiss goes on and on.  Peggy loses control and screams.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cont'd) Maggie!!!!? Like a bucket of water thrown on two dogs, Ike and Maggie are startled out of their kiss.  They pull apart and smile at each other. ANGLE ON:  Bob.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cont'd) (furious) If you were imagining me, you did great. (to Ike) What the hell were you doing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (eyes on Maggie) I'm sorry, Bob.  She kissed me back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (dazed but happy) I kissed him back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, I caught that.  Want to tell me how long this has been going on? Maggie looks at Ike, wondrous, confused.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: About a minute...?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A little longer for me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Really?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you expect me to say to this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How about -- "I hope you'll be very happy together"? Bob hauls back and punches Ike in the face.  Ike drops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hope you'll be very happy together. Bob storms down the aisle and out of the church.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Peggy) Take care of him. Maggie leaves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : EXT. CHURCH - THAT MOMENT Bob is halfway down the walk.  Maggie appears at the church door and calls after him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bob, I'm sorry! (half to herself) At least I backed out before the wedding.  That's progress! He keeps marching.  Now Peggy appears next to Maggie.  Maggie calls again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cont'd) Some woman is going to make you a lot happier than I ever could... The words are barely out of her mouth when Cindy comes out the door, racing after Bob at a full sprint.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cont'd) See?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, Maggie -- in the words of Mrs. Pressman: "Holy moly".  Call me later. Peggy goes to her car.  Cindy joins her as Bob speeds off in his car.  Now Ike takes Peggy's place next to Maggie.  Maggie turns to face Ike.  They are both beet red, stammering and unable to look at each other, trying to act normal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay.  So... what, uh... What just happened?  Just now?  Jus then?  In there?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know.  I, uh -- I frankly don't even want to talk about it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Me, either. Ike GRABS Maggie and BOOM -- they are all over each other, kissing frantically, tongues, hands, hair, elbow, you name it. Blathering fools.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (blathering) I love you.  I love you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (blathering) I love you, too. They come up for air.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wait.  We have to talk.  We have to do some talking now.  Pull up a railing. Maggie sits on the railing, then Ike backs up and sits on the opposite railing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cont'd) You have to go down an aisle and say "I do".  You have to get married.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To who?  Are you asking me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Me? Ike backs up to opposite railing and sits facing Maggie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, you!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (thinks) Well, you do have the dress.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And the church.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And the wedding date.  There's the two of us. (beat) So, you think... maybe... You have to go down the aisle with somebody you love and who love you back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm okay with that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So am I.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So, we'll... They both nod and sit there smiling, sort of. The organist, Ted, closes the church door. TED Good night. Ike pulls his tape recorder out of his pocket and quietly speaks into it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm getting married. WIDE SHOT: They smile at each other and remain sitting.  Then, silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : EXT. STREET/HALE/ATLANTIC HOTEL - THAT NIGHT Ike drives up and parks in front of the hotel as he talks on his cell phone. INTERCUT WITH: INT. FISHER AND ELLIE'S BEDROOM (NYC) - NIGHT Ellie's on the phone.  Fisher sits nearby.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ike's going to get married. Fisher throws himself onto the carpet and rolls himself helpless with laughter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cont'd) (without turning to him) Fisher, if you pee on that Persian, I'll kill you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : INT. BEAUTY SALON - NIGHT DAY Maggie talks to Peggy, Cindy and Grandma Julia.  Grandma Julia sits under a hair dryer.  Sprout, the dog, sits in his basket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I love his eyes.  I just believe they're listening to you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His hair... any color.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I like his tight butt. Peggy laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Grandma!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Cindy) See, this is a mature relationship. She's really found it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : LOVE MONTAGE SHOTS: EXT. OCEAN - DAY Ike and Maggie fishing. INT. MAGGIE'S WORKSHOP/HOME - DAY They play ping-pong.  They laugh, enjoying the moment. INT. MAGGIE'S HOUSE - DAY Ike and Maggie have fun playing cards.  The game is slapjack. EXT. FIELD - DAY Maggie and Ike horseback riding.  They sit on their horses amongst trees, "nuzzling".  Ike reads as he pushes Maggie in a tire swing. INT. MAGGIE'S ROOM - DAY Ike and Maggie open and close a Hoberman ball by holding its opposite ends in their teeth.  Grandma looks in. INT. MAGGIE'S LIVING ROOM - NIGHT There is a fire in the fireplace.  Maggie and Ike sit as Ike shows Maggie some passages from his favorite books.  He's reading something from Yeats at the moment.  They seem happy. EXT. CHURCH - THE DAY OF THE WEDDING It is a media circus including FOUR REPORTERS, Midday with Meredith and the T-shirt Vendor.  Plus three other people the reporters are interviewing, a GERMAN LADY, BUTCH KENAN, a farmer and Grandma Julia.  Reporter DINA NAPOLI walks down the church steps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wedding bells are ringing for the fourth time today in Hale, Maryland. Maggie Carpenter, "Always a Bride -- Never a Bridesmaid", will be attempting to complete her fourth wedding ceremony. We'll come back on the air when the results are in.  Back to you, Jessica. Meredith, the low-end public access TV reporter, films himself pointing a cheap video camera himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The turnout for this morning's wedding is usually reserved for royalty or Hollywood stars, but Maggie Carpenter is Hale, Maryland's special star and the citizens of Hale are out in full force today. The NY T-shirt Vendor pitches his wares.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I got "Bye-bye Birdie".  "What part of 'I do' don't you understand?"... Get your "Runaway Bride" T-shirts here... Reporter JULIE MURPHY stands near Grandma Julia and Mrs. Pressman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (Channel 6) The bride's been here for almost an hour, but being around in the beginning was never her problem.  We'll be here, showing you the full wedding ceremony, we hope. Reporter JACKI and TIFFANY stand at the edge of the CROWD reporting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: #3 (WBOC TV16) Will she or won't she?  That is on the minds of these several hundreds folks, who are standing here this morning. Not to mention on the mind of Groom Number #4, ex-USA Today columnist, Ike Graham, who is missing in action. EXT. WINDOW OF CHURCH/INT. SUNDAY SCHOOL ROOM - DAY INSERT window of church.  Peggy peers out the window at the carnival scene.  Cindy sits with Maggie as she leans forward, doubled over on a child's chair.  Peggy moves from the window to sit with them.

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's here!... He's here!

direction.raw_text: Now's the time for calm... If you don't calm down, you won't get your dress on... (reassuringly) He's the one... He's the one. Peggy moves to help Cindy with the dress.  Maggie stands alone at the window a moment.  She picks up a toy horse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is not a good sign. Maggie goes over to Peggy and Cindy, and starts to get into her bridal gown.  They continue to ad lib words standing with the letter "V".

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ike Graham is here! IKE'SPOV: He moves as he takes it all in:  a FAMILY eats a fast food picnic on a neighbor's lawn, invited GUESTS flock by in their party best, and local NEWS TEAMS block the way.  The STATE SENATOR is making a speech welcoming the press to Maryland.  A large GROUP of reporters head up the church's stairs, hauling their equipment.  They enter the flood of PEOPLE streaming inside the church.  Ike snaps. EXT. IKE'S CAR - CONTINUING Ike stops the car where it is and jumps out, slamming the door in anger.  The REPORTERS swarm around him as he gets out of the car. They continue to pound him with questions as he walks to church steps.  An OLDER LADY smacks him on the shoulder with a newspaper.  He turns in astonishment and continues up the steps.  He charges up the stairs and grabs Lee.

direction.raw_text: Shoot ours so she has one with an ending. Mrs. Pressman stands, shooting Ike with her video camera.

CHURCH - CONTINUING As Fisher and Ellie sign the guest book, a LOCAL LADY stares at Ellie.  Ellie stares back at her until she leaves.  Ike walks away from Lee and turns smack into Ellie and Fisher.  Ike puts his arms around them and gives them a big hug.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Friends.  Thank you.  Thank you. Over Ellie's shoulder, Ike sees Fisher's grinning face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I'm good, I don't know if I'm best.

direction.name: direction

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cont'd) I'll have a car around the back to whisk you out of here if she runs. Ellie kisses him on the cheek and walks away. ANGLE ON: Bob comes up to Ike.  He looks like he's going to punch Ike, then abruptly holds out a rose boutonniere.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You look awful.

direction.raw_text: (sarcastically) Thank you. Bob hands the flower to Ike.  Ike is shaking.  Bob catches this and looks up to Ike.  It is a moment of clean honesty between the men.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ike.  Need help? He takes the boutonniere and puts it on Ike's lapel.

direction.raw_text: Got any last minute advice?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (motioning to their eyes) Maintain eye contact. Bob turns and leaves, going down a side staircase.

direction.raw_text: (to himself) Eye contact.  Eye contact. Out of the corner of his eye, Ike sees a pictures of Christ on the wall.  He leans into the picture and whispers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cont'd) Cover me. He walks into the chapel. INT. CHAPEL - CONTINUING Ike steps up and stands next to Fisher.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Ike) I have no idea what I'm doing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your job is... the ring. (to Fisher) Do you have the ring?!

direction.raw_text: I just found out I'm best man!  I'm lucky I have a suit... What's wrong? Ike gives the ring to Fisher.  The Pastor approaches Ike.  Ike turns away and look out over the guests. IKE'SPOV:  There are most of the TOWNSPEOPLE we've come to know, plus some NEW YORKERS for Ike, with little ponytails. Armani wire rims, Donna Karan bodysuits.  There's a lot of smirking, checking out the hicks, forming their stories for cocktail hour.  Elaine is in back all dressed in black, mourning Ike.  Mrs. Trout approaches Ike.

direction.raw_text: Thank you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello.  I'm Fisher.

direction.raw_text: . TROUT This doesn't want to come out.

direction.raw_text: You just pull a hair from my neck.
direction.name: direction

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good luck, Maggie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you, Grandma. Grandma leaves.  Walter steps up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (quietly to Maggie) I'm really rooting for this one.

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Spit. Maggie spits her bubblegum into the bag.  Peggy hands Maggie her bouquet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's go.
direction.name: direction

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi, I'm Elaine from New York.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello.  I'm Bob, Maggie's fourth attempt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's okay.  There's a lid for every pot.  Besides, I'm comfortable with Ike. I mean, Jack Dempsey lost his heavyweight title to a New Yorker.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know.  Gene Tunney. The organ begins to play.  The organist is Ted.  Grandma, Walter, Mrs. Pressman and the Trouts watch.  Mrs. Trout picks lint off of her husband's jacket. ANGLE ON: Cindy and Peggy enter with the confident air of people who have done this before.  They make it to the head of the aisle all too quickly.  Peggy gives Ike a wink and an encouraging smile. INT. CHURCH FOYER - CONTINUING The door opens and Dennis sticks his head in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're ready, Maggie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just a second. Dennis closes the door behind him as he goes back into the chapel.  Maggie has a moment alone.  She looks at back door as possible escape route, then changes her mind.  She signals the start of the wedding by knocking on the door. INT. CHAPEL - CONTINUOUS Immediately, Cory and Dennis open the doors for her entrance. All the guests stand as Maggie enter the chapel smiling. MAGGIE'S POV: The aisle stretches before her into infinity.  Faces goggle at her from every direction.  The tiny figure of Ike stands like a beacon a long way off. NEW ANGLE: She plunges forward with a sped-up hesitation step. ANGLE ON: Ike rocks imperceptibly, urging her on.  Peggy and Cindy make little "come on" motions.  It seems to be working.  Maggie approaches rapidly.  The CROWD has turned from skepticism to looks and noises of encouragement. ANGLE ON: MAGGIE But then her feet gradually begin to slow. ANGLE ON: Fisher gives a little "darn, so close" look. ANGLE ON: But Ike is too busy maintaining eye contact.  His eyes urge Maggie closer -- loving her, willing her on. CLOSE ON: Maggie stops her walk, gives Ike a teasing smile, and then resumes with her walk toward him.  His face.  Her face.  His face.  Her face. CLOSE ON: Her foot inches forward.  The other follows. NEW ANGLE: A sigh now rises from the GUESTS as Maggie closes in on Ike.  He smiles at her.  She smiles at him.  She is almost there... She's there, smiling at Ike.  The Pastor gestures to the guests to sit down.  They do. ANGLE ON: Ike sneezes.  She looks down and imagines she sees the carpet splitting apart.  And she bolts like a bat out of hell!  In a flurry of white, she is halfway down the aisle before Ike knows what hits him. ANGLE ON: Ike stands there dazed.  For a second.  Then she springs into action, charging after her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (yelling out) Block the doors! Like a general, he points to Dennis and Cory in the back and sends them into action.  The doors shut in Maggie's face.  But she's a wild animal cornered.   She moves to the side.  The TOWNSPEOPLE stand so Ike can hurry through the pew.  Ike climbs on the pews towards her as GUEST crowd the aisle, blocking his path.  Like a gazelle, she leaps to the side aisle and scampers down and away.  Fisher gets on his cell phone.  Ike charges from one of the full pews, crosses the aisle and leaps across the pews near the staircase to cut her off.  He grabs her veil and it comes off in his hands.  Maggie disappears down the steps of the church basement.  Ike fumble with the veil and jumps over the railing, landing on Dennis' toe.  He follows down the stairs after her.  Mrs. Pressman and Walter exchange bet money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's a man coming down those steps with lots of candy in his pockets.  If you tickle him, he'll give candy. She gives her bouquet to a little GIRL as she goes by.  Ike comes down stairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maggie! The KIDS mob him, grabbing his pockets.  Ike fights his way through KIDS. ANGLE ON: Maggie as she's in the church kitchen and hops on counter and heads out the window.  The window is wide enough. ANGLE ON: Ike as he gets to the window, but Maggie is out in driveway. EXT. CHURCH DRIVEWAY - CONTINUING Maggie flies toward a FedEx truck at next house just leaving. ANOTHER ANGLE: She gathers her dress and jumps in as Ike yells from window, then, quickly climbs out onto the lawn as the truck starts to pull away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maggie! Maggie looks back once, tearful and regretful, and disappears inside the truck.  The truck races off. The PHOTOGRAPHERS turn their cameras on Ike, en masse.  He is enveloped by a barrage of bright lights. Ellie and Fisher, who have also stepped outside on chapel front steps, are looking around as Ike turns around the corner and past the church.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look, he's running after her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look, he's in pretty good shape.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Poor Ike. They look after the FedEx truck and watch Ike chasing the truck down the road away from the church.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (running; yells) Maggie!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where do you think she's going?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wherever it is, she'll be there by ten- thirty tomorrow. Cindy, Cory, Peggy and Meredith also rush out of the church and comment on Maggie's runaway.  Further down the road, Ike still chases the truck, yelling:
direction.name: direction

result.heading: "MAGGIE'S MAD DASH" "HARDWARE HONEY GOES NUTS AND BOLTS" "JOURNALIST WRITTEN OFF" "BRIDE TAKES HIKE

direction.raw_text: Maggie! As the truck rounds the bend in the road and disappears, Ike stops and stares alone after the disappearing truck.  A swarm of REPORTERS catch up to him, flashing pictures and asking questions.  Another camera flashes and we cut to: A NEWSPAPER PHOTO Of Ike's stunned face on the cover of the USA Today.  The caption reads: "Hit and Run:  Runaway Bride Strikes again".  And we see headlines in other papers. "MAGGIE'S MAD DASH" "HARDWARE HONEY GOES NUTS AND BOLTS" "JOURNALIST WRITTEN OFF" "BRIDE TAKES HIKE...NOT IKE" "BRIDE TAKE RIDE" "MAGGIE SAYS I DON'T" NEWSPAPER MONTAGE: INT. NEW YORK BAR - DAY Kevin, the bartender, reads Jay's column, in the USA Today entitled "Maggie's Mad Dash".
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : EXT. USA TODAY LOADING DOCK - DAY Various newspaper WORKERS also read Jay's column in the USA Today entitled "Maggie Mad Dash" and "Hardware Honey Goes Nuts and Bolts" in another newspaper. FADE IN EXT. MAIN STREET/HALE - NIGHT (1-5 MONTHS LATER) It's a night like any other in Hale -- the regular order of things has been restored on its quaint streets.  Quartet sings in front of the hotel.  LEE AND CORY CHUFFA:  About where Peggy is. INT. HARDWARE STORE - NIGHT Maggie is sitting, end of a long day.  Peggy sticks her head in entrance door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You okay?  I'm closing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm just finishing up, too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Want to go to Butch's for a drink or something?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (interrupting) No, I'm just going to head home.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay. Peggy starts to go, then moves close to Maggie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cont'd) (stepping closer and making a "V" with her fingers) You know, I was just thinking about that geese thing.  I think the "V" was half of a "W".  A "W" for...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you talking about?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wedding.  Wedding. (holding Maggie's face) You just have to get the rest of your ducks in a row.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you.  You still think that he was....
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Quick.  Very quick. Peggy exits.  Maggie stares, losing herself in thought.  Then a VOICE startles her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (whispers) Marry me, Maggie. Maggie jumps and turns to see:  DENNIS -- the kid from the high school football team, popping up from a low position near the counter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (softly) Hi, Dennis.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am going to propose, you know.  I mean, the right way.  Soon as I turn eighteen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're sweet, Dennis.  But you've got to go.  I'm closing up.  Here's a candy bar and one for your brother. Dennis takes the candy and starts to go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not giving up.   A person shouldn't give up. Dennis exits.  Maggie is alone.  She turns out the lamp she designed, then on again.  She turns off the other lamp on the counter and exits.  We hold on Maggie's designed lamp.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : INT. IKE'S HALLWAY AND APARTMENT - NIGHT Ike walks up to his door, carrying his mail and a bag of carryout.  He opens the door and walks into his apartment.  He pets Italics, who sits on his sofa bed.  Without taking off his coat, he goes to his keyboard and plays music as he CHUFFAS to his cat about marriage and divorce.

direction.raw_text: : INT. MAGGIE'S HOUSE - DAY Dad and Grandma Julia are there.  Grandma is making lunch. Walter is juggling oranges.  There's glass of beer on the kitchen counter.

direction.raw_text: ! Walter looks at his daughter in surprise.  He's never heard a tone like this in her voice before.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (quiet fury) Just stop it.  Don't say another word like that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (putting down the oranges) Maggie, it's just a joke...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.  It's my life.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A harmless joke.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, it's humiliating and you've been doing it since I was a kid.  I don't like it.  Stop.  You may not like having a daughter with problems.  But guess what?  I don't like having a father who's drunk all the time.  I'll eat in my room. Maggie takes a plate and exits.

direction.raw_text: That needed to be said.  You know -- you're always making jokes about her, so they won't make jokes about your drinking. Walter reacts.
direction.name: direction

direction.name: direction

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : INT. IKE'S APARTMENT - ANOTHER DAY Ike quietly sits in bed writing and staring into space thinking. His cat sits on the windowsill.
direction.name: direction

direction.name: direction

MAGGIE'S KITCHEN - DAY Maggie in front of plates full of all sorts of types of eggs -- scrambled, poached, sunny-side up, Benedict, soft boiled, etc -- sits on the kitchen counter.  She ties them all. EXT. NEW YORK STREET - DAY Establishing shot.  Two MEN try to fix the engine of a taxi outside the restaurant.
